entry.title: Doha agreement brings DR Congo government and M23 rebels a step closer to peace
entry.summary: An agreement signed by the Government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and the Congo River Alliance/March 23 Movement (AFC/M23) has been hailed by the UN peacekeeping mission in the country (MONUSCO) as â€œan important step towards sustainable peace.â€

entry.title: A practical guide to long-distance walking in the UK
entry.summary:
There are now 16 official National Trails extending across the length and breadth of England and Wales. There is tremendous fun to be had striding across dale and over fell, up mountain gradient and along the precipice of a wildflower-capped sea cliff, but with so many designated walks to choose from, what should you know before setting off?
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Long-distance rambling in Britain is part ofÂ aÂ correspondingly long tradition. In fact, few nationalities enjoy it quite as much as the British: from the South West Coast Path at Landâ€™s End in Cornwall, to the Cape Wrath Trail in the Scottish Highlands, you'll always find a Brit in an anorak. In 1965, the Pennine Way became the first of the UK's National Trails, and now â€” 6â€¦

entry.title: Desks become beds as Haitian school shelters people displaced by violence
entry.summary: Gang violence in Haiti has displaced hundreds of thousands of people and many are finding shelter in former schools where belief in the power of education remains strong.

entry.title: This hidden Italian town is perfect for a summer escape
entry.summary:
Evade the summer holiday crowds along Italy's most popular coastlines and head to Basilicata instead. Known as the â€˜Pearl of the Tyrrhenianâ€™, this little-known stretch of Basilicata goes all out on natural beauty and southern Italian charm. Here's how to spend a leisurely weekend in Maratea.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Imagine if the Amalfi Coast was all but unknown â€” thatâ€™s the charm of Maratea. Bordered by Campania to the north and Calabria to the south, the municipality occupies the only portion of the Tyrrhenian coast in the whole of Basilicata. Itâ€™s a near 20-mile stretch home to striking black-sand beaches, boat-fresh seafood and panoramic vistas overlooking the glittering Gulf of Policastro. But despite possessing all the hallmarksâ€¦

entry.title: Who was Nelson Mandela?
entry.summary:
Former South African president and civil rights advocate Nelson Mandela dedicated his life to fighting for equalityâ€”and ultimately helped topple South Africa's racist system of apartheid. His accomplishments are now celebrated each year on July 18, Nelson Mandela International Day.

This activist dedicated his life to dismantling racismâ€”and went from being the worldâ€™s most famous political prisoner to South Africaâ€™s first Black president. Nelson Mandela was born on July 18, 1918, in what was then known as the Union of South Africa, a dominion of the British Empire. Although the majority of the countryâ€™s inhabitants were Black, they were dominated by a white minority population that controlled the land, the wealth, and the governmentâ€”a discriminatory social structure thaâ€¦

entry.title: My best summers were spent at Grand Canyon Lodgeâ€”now itâ€™s gone
entry.summary:
Iâ€™m not usually one to get weepy over a hotel, let alone a patio and some rough-hewn wooden furniture. But when Arizonaâ€™s famous Grand Canyon Lodge and a number of smaller adjacent structures burned down on the night of July 12 in the Dragon Bravo Fire, a blaze that to date has consumed 11,344 acres and remains entirely uncontained, it left a hole in more than just the conifer forest of the North Rim. My heart, my friendsâ€™ heartsâ€”thereâ€™s a hole in each of these now. And there are similar holes in the hearts of thousands of folks across the globe who also loved, and still love, and will forever love, that rustic palace, that gobsmacking view, that superlative place.
In 2024, close to five million visitors experienced the beauty and wonder of Grand Canyon National Park, but only ten perâ€¦

entry.title: See 100 years of New York City
entry.summary:
In the summer of 1957, a replica of the Mayflower sailed into New York Harbor. Dubbed the Mayflower II, it had just finished retracing the Pilgrimsâ€™ 1620 journey across the Atlantic to establish a colony in America. New York City celebrated its arrival with a ticker-tape parade.
That November, National Geographic published an article written by the shipâ€™s captain about the Mayflower IIâ€™s voyage, full of photos of its ocean journey and a victorious arrival in New York City (which was not a stop on the original shipâ€™s route to Plymouth, Massachusetts).
As the city this year celebrates the 400th anniversary of its founding as the Dutch outpost New Amsterdam, National Geographic looked back on its coverage of the city over the last century.
An early article highlighted its drawsâ€¦

entry.title: Felix Baumgartner, famed pilot and BASE jumper, dies at 56
entry.summary:
Felix Baumgartner, the world-renowned Austrian pilot who was named National Geographicâ€™s 2013Â Peopleâ€™s Choice Adventurer of the YearÂ for his fearless aerial feats, has died in Italy.Â
According to local mediaÂ reports, the pilot died after crashing into a hotel pool while paragliding on the Adriatic coast, injuring another person in the accident.
National Geographic has reached out to Baumgartnerâ€™s representatives.
According to the Associated Press, the cityâ€™s mayor confirmed Baumgartnerâ€™s death in a social media post.
â€œOur community is deeply affected by the tragic disappearance of Felix Baumgartner, a figure of global prominence, a symbol of courage and passion for extreme flight,â€ Mayor Massimiliano Ciarpella said.Â
Baumgartner leaves behind a soaring legacy, setâ€¦

entry.title: This underdiagnosed vein disorder affects 4 in 10 Americans
entry.summary:
A nurse practitioner examines a patient with chronic venous insufficiency (CVI), a vascular condition in which damaged leg veins impair blood flow back to the heart. CVI can lead to symptoms such as swelling, skin changes, and venous ulcers if left untreated. From tingly legs to bulging veins, these warning signs may point to chronic venous insufficiencyâ€”a widespread circulatory issue doctors say is on the rise.
Swelling, aching calves, tingling, or bulging veins might seem like everyday discomforts, but they could point to a hidden problem in your circulatory system. A surprisingly common yet underrecognized condition called chronic venous insufficiency is behind a growing number of casesâ€”and scientists say itâ€™s far more widespread than most people realize.
Here are five thinâ€¦

entry.title: Wellness is going high tech at these hotels
entry.summary:
In addition to massages and facials, hotel spas are adding in space-age wellness treatments to their services. All-natural treatments like aromatherapy and mud facials used to be all the rage. But now, top hotels around the world are offering something decidedly different.
Natural treatments and products have long been wellness buzzwordsâ€”think of aromatherapy sessions using plant-derived ingredients, or skin-smoothing immersions in mineral-rich volcanic mud. But now, a different approach is on the rise.
â€œWhatâ€™s becoming more common is a model where everything is scientifically calibrated,â€ says Amy Larocca, author of the recent book How to Be Well: Navigating Our Self-Care Epidemic, One Dubious Cure at a Time, a skepticâ€™s take on wellness culture in the United States.
On â€¦

entry.title: What do you do with thousands of dead Everglades pythons?
entry.summary: Just after midnight, Elle Barbeito drove her Dodge pickup deep into the shadows of the Florida Everglades. After hours navigating narrow marsh roads, past towering bald cypresses and raucous shoots of bromeliads, she suddenly pulled onto the shoulder and aimed a flashlight at a writhing patch of prehistoric-looking ferns. â€œPython!â€ Barbeito shouted, pointing to a metallic sheen of scales glistening like silken chain mail in the moonlight. The next part would require her gun.Â https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngm-2507-Python-Fashion-Map/builds/main/html/_graphic.html No one can say for certain how Burmese pythons arrived in the Everglades in the first place or how many there are today, though conservative estimates put their population in the tens of thousands. What weâ€¦

entry.summary: The UN humanitarian affairs office OCHA is stressing the need to scale up support for displaced families in Haiti amid ongoing insecurity and violence.

entry.title: UN envoy urges Colombia to â€˜stay the courseâ€™ as peace faces new strains
entry.summary: Colombia has changed profoundly since the 2016 peace deal, but uneven state presence, lingering armed groups and mounting political tensions threaten to erode confidence unless implementation accelerates, the top UN envoy for the country said on Friday.

entry.summary: Major cuts to aid budgets have already left people fleeing wars in Sudan and beyond without the assistance and protection they need, the UN refugee agency, UNHCR,Â said on Friday.

entry.title: Syria crisis: Hundreds killed in ongoing violence, hospitals overwhelmed
entry.summary: Amid violent clashes in southern Syriaâ€™s Sweida governorate, a picture of grave human rights abuses and rising humanitarian needs is emerging by the hour, the UN said on Friday.

entry.title: As war rages on in Ukraine, organised crime is taking new forms
entry.summary: Almost four years after Russiaâ€™s full-scale invasion, criminal groups in Ukraine are adapting their business models amid displacement, rising trafficking risks and an increased demand for synthetic drugs, the UN Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) said in a report published on Friday.

entry.title: The best place to snorkle with whale sharks? It's in Australia
entry.summary:
Whale sharks, humpbacks, southern right whales, orcas, mighty mantas, turtles and some 700 species of fish await just offshore, often within paddling distance of the beachâ€™s windblown dunes. Whale sharks, coral reefs and safari tents amid the dunes: this remote lodge immerses travellers in Western Australiaâ€™s astounding marine world.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The Ningaloo Coast is where outback, reef and ranges meet. Here, on the northwestern fringes of Australia, 745 miles above Perth on a rocky thumb of a promontory that juts into the Indian Ocean, great ochre canyons and stretches of flat, red earth slip into water thatâ€™s as bright blue as a kingfisher. This is also where marine giants meet â€” among them whale sharks, humpbacks, southâ€¦

entry.title: Tornadoes, explained
entry.summary:
Tornadoes are vertical funnels of rapidly spinning air. Their winds may top 250 miles an hour and can clear a pathway a mile wide and 50 miles long.
Twisters are born in thunderstorms and are often accompanied by hail. Giant, persistent thunderstorms called supercells spawn the most destructive.
These violent storms occur around the world, but the United States is a major hotspot, with the number of tornadoes clocking in at about 1,200 per year.
â€œTornado Alley,â€ a region that includes the area in the eastern state of South Dakota, Nebraska, Kansas, Oklahoma, northern Texas, and eastern Colorado, is often home to the most powerful and destructive of these storms. U.S. tornadoes cause 80 deaths and more than 1,500 injuries per year, according to the National Weather Service. â€¦

entry.title: A photographer's guide to Texas
entry.summary:
From the geological wonders of Big Bend National Park to the scenic coastlines of Corpus Christi, Texas is a land of infinite varietyâ€”and endless photographic inspiration. On assignment, National Geographic photographer Tara Kerzhner set out to capture the spirit and soul of the Lone Star State through its dramatic landscapes, local characters, and hidden corners. What she found was a place full of adventures and breathtaking beauty at every turn.
Here, she shares some of her favorite images and the moments behind them. undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined

entry.title: A coastal adventure along the Texas Gulf
entry.summary:
Thereâ€™s a certain magic to the Texas Gulf Coastâ€”especially in and around Corpus Christiâ€”where the warm sea breeze carries the scent of salt and adventure. Itâ€™s a place that feels both untamed and inviting, where coastal experiences unfold at every turn. Whether youâ€™re watching migratory birds soar overhead, riding horseback along the shoreline on Mustang Island, savoring freshly caught Gulf seafood at a dockside eatery, or sailing into a blazing sunset on Corpus Christi Bay, each moment draws you deeper into the rhythm of life by the sea.
Discover the natural beauty and coastal charm of the Texas Gulf Coastâ€”one photo at a time. undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined

entry.title: Photo story: Exploring the rugged beauty of Big Bend, Texas
entry.summary:
Big skies. Bigger adventures. Welcome to Big Bendâ€”West Texasâ€™ untamed trifecta of mountains, river valleys, and desert landscapes. Itâ€™s a place that feels raw and remote, yet deeply soulful, where every trail, canyon, and star-filled sky invites exploration. Whether youâ€™re hiking through the dramatic peaks of the Chisos Mountains, paddling the Rio Grande through ancient limestone canyons, or simply watching the landscape come alive at golden hour, every moment here connects you to something wild and timeless.
Experience the rugged beauty and enduring spirit of Big Bendâ€”one photo at a time. undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined undefined

entry.title: Photo story: A window into West Texas culture
entry.summary:
Where vast horizons meet dynamic expression, West Texas unfolds as a canvas of culture, history, and creativity. From the striking art installations of Marfa to the historic charm of Alpine and Marathon, this region pulses with a unique spirit that blends frontier grit with cultural innovation. Whether youâ€™re exploring outdoor galleries or staying in one-of-a-kind accommodations, West Texas invites you to discover a world where art, culture, and heritage come alive against a backdrop of sweeping vistas and endless skies.
Experience the spirit and soul of West Texasâ€”one frame at a time.
Roll Gate (2022) by Charles Harlan features a single roll-down gateâ€”typically used to secure storefrontsâ€”reimagined as a freestanding sculpture. Golden-hour light casts a visitorâ€™s shadow across adobe-style structures in Marfa. Sam Falls' installation Life in California (2023) features a red truck transformed by the elements and time. Visible in the background is Matt Johnson's Sleeping Figure (2023).Â Each installation invites a different view of the West Texas landscape.
undefined undefined

entry.title: What is methylene blue and can it really boost your brain power?
entry.summary:
A solution of methylene blue in an erlenmeyer flask. The trending dye was invented by German chemist Heinrich Caro in 1876. The trendy supplement was originally developed as a fabric dyeâ€”and later used as a malaria treatment. We asked experts if it really has the cognitive benefits touted on social media.
If youâ€™ve spotted someone recently with a blue tongue, that inky stain could actually be the side effect of a new health trend.
Biohacking enthusiasts have been using a substance calledÂ methylene blueÂ as a daily supplement, sharing videos of their stained tongues on TikTok. Users claim the highly pigmented compound, which was originally developed as a fabric dye before being used for medical purposes, can improveÂ cognitive function,Â energy levelsÂ andÂ mood, and could even prevâ€¦

entry.title: Skeleton reveals that some ancient women were extreme hermits
entry.summary:
Today the most extreme forms of devotion to God in Christianity involve tithing, abstaining from meat on Fridays and during Lent, taking religious orders and devoting oneself to a life of celibacy, and, perhaps, taking vows of poverty or even silence.
All of these practices pale next to the forms of asceticism practiced in the Byzantine period, when the most dedicated monks isolated themselves from human contact in the desert, restricted their food and sleep, wrapped themselves in uncomfortable sore-inducing chains, and lived their lives on top of small pillars.
Traditionally, the most hardcore ascetics were believed to have been men, but recent scholarly and archeological research has revealed that female monastics were equally devoted to self-mortification.
In 1924, excavaâ€¦

entry.title: Blowing out birthday candles is surprisingly ancient
entry.summary:
If youâ€™ve been to a birthday party, youâ€™ve probably seen it: the cake comes out, the candles are lit, the room sings, and the birthday person makes a wish before blowing them out. Itâ€™s a moment we donâ€™t think twice aboutâ€”but it didnâ€™t start as just a party tradition.
From moonlit offerings in ancient Greece to protective spells in medieval Germany, birthday candles were once used to invoke blessings, ward off misfortune, and represent the delicate balance between life and death.
So, how did a spiritual ritual evolve into a party trick? Hereâ€™s how cultures around the world have used fire, food, and celebration to mark the passage of time.
The history of birthday candles
While itâ€™s commonly said that the tradition of birthday candles began in ancient Greece, thereâ€™s no diâ€¦

entry.title: Scientists record a black hole collision they werenâ€™t sure was possible
Scientists are racing to develop a â€˜living computerâ€™
entry.summary:
Scientists are experimenting with ways to integrate brain cells into computer processors. The technology could help conserve energy. FinalSpark's Multi-Electrode Arrays (MEAs) incorporate four human brain organoids, each interfacing with eight electrodes. The potential for these kinds of machines to reshape computer processing, increase energy efficiency, and revolutionize medical testing has scientists excited. But when do we consider these cells to be conscious?
In 2022, a group of Australian researchers ran a rudimentary simulation of the arcade game, Pong. None of them were controlling the virtual paddle, and yet, after a few misses, the paddle moved up and down the screen on its own to meet the returning ball and hit it back.
The 2D game was wired to a cluster of lab-groâ€¦

entry.title: This untamed island is the Caribbeanâ€™s best-kept secret
entry.summary:
Mount Scenery, a dormant volcano, is the highest point in the Kingdom of the Netherlands. There are no traffic lights, no high-rises, no beaches, and no crowds on tiny Saba. Instead, youâ€™ll find misty mountains, epic hikes, and vibrant reefs.
Located 28 miles from St. Maarten, the five-square-mile island of Saba isnâ€™t the first place that springs to mind when it comes to adventure travel. Draped in wild greenery from every angle, this volcanic island looks almost vacant from afar. With no traffic lights, no high-rises, no beaches, and no crowds, it remains relatively under the radar as one of the smallest inhabited islands in the Caribbean.Â
However, that same remoteness is exactly what once made Saba both uninviting and intriguing. In 1493, the island caught the eye of Christâ€¦

entry.title: Hereâ€™s why stargazers are flocking to the Oregon Outback
entry.summary:
DarkSky International has designated more than 2.4 million acres in Southeast Oregon, including Lake County, as a dark sky sanctuary, making it the largest in the world. The largest dark sky sanctuary in the world is 2.4 million acres of volcanic landscape, deserts, and mountains. Learn how to plan your trip.
Southeast OregonÂ is a patchwork of high desert, mountains, and volcanic landscape, stitched together by river canyons and long stretches of solitude.Â When darkness falls on clear nightsÂ across this region, visitors can watch a shimmering blanket of stars emerge.Â
In March 2024, The 2.4-million-acre Oregon OutbackÂ officially becameÂ the largest dark sky sanctuaryÂ in the world.Â DarkSky International, an organization dedicated to preserving dark places to mitigate the harmfulâ€¦

entry.title: How magnesium affects your sleep and anxiety
entry.summary: Magnesium is an important mineral that can help with muscle soreness, migraines, blood pressure, osteoporosis, and potentially even lower the risks of bone fractures, heart disease, type 2 diabetes, and stroke. But experts say it's not clear everyone needs to take supplementsâ€”nor that it really helps with sleep and anxiety as many have claimed on social media. The essential mineral is important for the bodyâ€”but it doesnâ€™t work miracles. Hereâ€™s wâ€¦

entry.title: UN chief reports progress in Cyprus talks, urges swift implementation of trust measures
entry.summary: Reporting â€œconstructiveâ€ discussions on Cyprus, UN Secretaryâ€‘General AntÃ³nio Guterres announced on Thursday that four previously agreed trustâ€‘building measures have been realized, technical work continues on two others, and the parties have agreed to expand cooperation on youth, environment, culture and civil society.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN sounds alarm over Syria as sectarian clashes and Israeli strikes escalate
entry.summary: A surge in sectarian violence in southern Syria and Israeli airstrikes reaching central Damascus have pushed the warâ€‘scarred country into a volatile juncture, a senior UN official said on Thursday, warning that renewed violence could shatter prospects for peace and fuel wider regional instability.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Violence spurs displacement in Syria, Israeli military moves in Lebanon, mall fire kills dozens in Iraq
entry.summary: The UN humanitarian office (OCHA) reported mass displacement in Swedia, Syria after five days of sectarian violence between Bedouin tribal fighters, government forces and Druze militias.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres deplores Israeli strike on Gaza church
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres has strongly condemned the Israeli strike on Thursday that hit the only Catholic church in the Gaza Strip.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: Emergency meeting on rising tensions in Syria
entry.summary: The Security Council met on Thursday afternoon for an emergency session on Syria after deadly violence in the south and a wave of Israeli airstrikes that reportedly hit military sites and key locations in Damascus. Khaled Khiari, a senior UN political affairs official briefed ambassadors, warning that renewed bloodshed could derail prospects for a credible, inclusive political transition and widen regional fault lines. UN News App users can follow here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Indigenous youth meet trailblazers ahead of Nelson Mandela Day
entry.summary: A group of Indigenous youth from the United States, some as young as seven, visited the United Nations Headquarters in New York this week for the first time.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Pakistan reels under monsoon deluge as death toll climbs
entry.summary: Pakistanâ€™s monsoon emergency deepened on Thursday as authorities declared disaster zones across parts of eastern Punjab state after lethal cloudbursts and flash floods killed dozens in a single day.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights chief condemns recent killing of scores of civilians in Sudan
entry.summary: The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Volker TÃ¼rk has deplored deadly attacks in Sudanâ€™s Kordofan region this week, his office said in a statement on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukraine: UN and partners launch Winter Response Plan amid escalating hostilities
entry.summary: As years of war in Ukraine have left millions without unreliable heating and limited means to pay rising utility costs, the UN and humanitarian partners launched this Thursday a $277 million appeal to support the most vulnerable people during the coming winter.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: From crisis to classroom: How the UN supports education in conflict zones
entry.summary: From makeshift furniture in Gaza to metro classrooms in Ukraine and solar-powered tablets in Sudan, the UN is working to bring education to millions of crisis-affected children.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Who wants to buy a piece of Mars?
entry.summary: The piece of Mars auctioned through Sotheby's. Weighing in at 54 pounds, this is the largest piece of Mars on Earth, and is the most valuable meteorite ever found. The largest piece of Mars on Earth became the most valuable meteorite ever sold at auction at Sothebyâ€™s annual â€Geek Week,â€ and a full Ceratosaurus skeleton fetched $30 million. Next up for bidding: an Apple computer hand-built by Steve Jobs. In the end, the long-dead dinosaur outperformed the largest piece of Mars ever found on Earth. At Sothebyâ€™s on Wednesday, an exhibition-ready, mounted skeleton of a 150-million-year-old dinosaurâ€”a juvenile Ceratosaurus nasicornisâ€”sold for $30.5 million (including fees and costs), far exceeding its estimate of $6 million. Meanwhile, the Mars-originating, 54-pound meteoritâ€¦

entry.title: What causes airplane turbulence?
entry.summary:
Mountains, storms, and the jet stream all affect airplane turbulence. Though it is usually more nerve-wracking than dangerous, a handful of passengers suffer injuries due to rough air each year. Turbulence can be scary, but hereâ€™s the science behind this natural phenomenonâ€”and tips to stay safe on a plane.
Turbulence is a normal part of air travel. Indeed, everyone has a story about hitting a rough patch of air, those hair-raising moments when suddenly more than the plane is flying. Bellies drop, drinks slop, and people caught in the aisle lurch against seats. In rare cases, it can even mean more than bumps or bruises.
In air travel, turbulence is a major source of flight anxiety for flyers of all stripes. But understanding what causes turbulence, where it occurs, and the highâ€¦

entry.title: Athens is reviving a 2,000-year-old ancient Roman aqueduct
entry.summary:
Athens, GreeceWhen Eleni Sotiriou and her neighbors turn on their taps in the coming weeks, theyâ€™ll be getting water from an ancient aqueduct connected to an ancient, underground waterway that many Athenians are unaware exists.
â€œItâ€™s very exciting that something built 2,000 years ago will be used by modern Greeks for such an important reason,â€ said Sotiriou, an environmentally conscious 65-year-old who admonishes neighbors for wasting dwindling drinking water on activities such as washing their cars. â€œWe have to be careful,â€ she said. â€œThere isnâ€™t an unlimited supply.â€
Sitting on Europeâ€™s sweltering southeastern border, Greece has been hard hit by a water crisis worsened by climate change. Last year, an acute shortage of rainfall prompted several Greek islands to ration water as â€¦

entry.title: Youâ€™re never too old for summer campâ€”these 8 getaways prove it
entry.summary:
At Paws Up Montana, adults can stay active and get those â€œsummer campâ€ vibes by participating in activities, such as cattle drives, whitewater rafting, and a ropes course. Put away your cellphone and spend your summer eating sâ€™mores, working on your backstroke, or taking up archery. These resorts cater to adults who need a break from adulting.
As a kid, you probably roasted marshmallows over bonfires, maybe learned to horseback ride or tie a knot, or canoed across mountain lakesâ€”all things that required presence rather than productivity. It sounded perfect then, and possibly even better now as an adult. â€œIt was those packed days and early-to-bed nights that reminded me so much of childhood spent at camp,â€ says Kate Loweth, recalling a recent visit to Paws Up Ranch in Montana, a plaâ€¦

entry.title: How did Jane Austen die? Still, nobody knows
entry.summary:
When Jane Austen died on July 18, 1817, at the age of 41, she left behind only six complete novelsâ€”and one of the most vexing medical mysteries of all time.
No one knows what exactly caused her death. But Austen experienced a curious assortment of symptoms late in life, ranging from recurring fevers and fatigue to stomach issues and concerns over her changing complexion.
The enduring mystery has piqued the interest of scholars and armchair sleuths alike, who have proposed a variety of medical conditions to explain her death, including cancer and accidental poisoning.
(Murder or madness: What really killed Edgar Allan Poe?)
The act of posthumously diagnosing Austen is part of a larger cottage industry of retrospective diagnosis, the practice of applying modern medical knâ€¦

entry.title: The age of your brain can predict how long youâ€™ll live
entry.summary:
Two groundbreaking studies show that measuring how fast your brain is aging could transform how we predict and prevent diseaseâ€”even before symptoms appear. Is your brain aging faster than your chronological age? New research shows it could raise your risk of death and dementia significantlyâ€”and offers promise for early intervention.
Old age comes for everyone, but how fast it happensâ€”and how healthy you remain when it doesâ€”can vary dramatically.
Groundbreaking new research makes it easier than ever to determine how fast your brain is agingâ€”and shows that having an â€œold" brain raises your risk of death by a striking 182 percent over about 15 years compared to people whose brains are aging normally.
In the first of two recent studies, Stanford University scientists found thâ€¦

entry.title: Step into the town behind the UK's royal regatta
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The River Thames has long been the lifeblood of Henley. For centuries, it welcomed merchant ships carrying wine and grain from London. Trade with the capital transformed it into a thriving port town, Tudor and Georgian townhouses steadily gilding the streets around its medieval marketplace. But it wasnâ€™t until 1839, when oars hit the water for the inaugural Henley Regatta, that the town made the leap from prosperous port to fashionable resort. Featuring more than 400 races spread out across the first week of July, the boating event now attracts over 300,000 visitors every year, with spectators gathering for riverside picnics at Remenham Farm, Temple Island and other vantage points.
The regatta remains a key corâ€¦

entry.title: The best window to see Pluto all year is closing
entry.summary:
Plutoâ€™s thin, blue haze glows in this image from NASAâ€™s New Horizons spacecraft. Though the dwarf planet is just a faint speck through a telescope, opposition this month offers skywatchers their best chance to spot it from Earth. A once-a-year alignment makes the dwarf planet easier to spotâ€”if you know where to look.
Think you can spot Pluto? On July 25, the famously elusive dwarf planet reaches oppositionâ€”its best and brightest moment of the year. That makes now the ideal time to try to catch a glimpse of it from your own backyard.
But be warned: Even at its brightest, Pluto is still a barely-there speck, even through a telescope. But for those willing to search, itâ€™s a cosmic scavenger huntâ€”and a rare chance to see a world nearly four billion miles away.

entry.title: We need to value women in sport, UN rights chief says
entry.summary: In the midst of the Womenâ€™s Euro football championship in Switzerland, Volker TÃ¼rk, the UN human rights chief, called on Member States and sports clubs around the world to address the vast gender gap which still exists in womenâ€™s sport.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza war: UN officials warn of unspeakable conditions as children bear the brunt
entry.summary: Conditions in Gaza have reached an unspeakable level of devastation with children paying the highest price, top UN officials told the Security Council on Wednesday, warning of soaring child deaths, starvation and a shattered health system amid continuing bombardment and displacement.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria: UN chief urges de-escalation as Sweida violence escalates, Israel strikes Damascus
entry.summary: Clashes between Bedouin tribal fighters, caretaker government forces and Druze militias stretched into their fourth day in Sweida on Wednesday while Israeli forces struck the Syrian capital, Damascus.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Haiti funding cuts bite, civilian suffering intensifies in Myanmar, Belarus deaths in custody alert
entry.summary: In violence-wracked Haiti, more than 5.7 million people are estimated to be food insecure, with many unable to meet their daily food needs.

entry.title: From diamonds to dirt: Sierra Leone youth bring land back to life
entry.summary: Craters filled with muddy water pocket the landscape of the Kono district inÂ Sierra Leone â€“ the result of past diamond mining ventures which sparked a vicious local battle over resources.

entry.title: Unprecedented Afghan returns are â€˜a test of our collective humanityâ€™
entry.summary: The international community must support Afghanistan as it grapples with the staggering number of citizens returning from the region, a senior UN official has said.

entry.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: â€˜Aid must go where needs are greatestâ€™ in Gaza, urges UN relief chief
entry.summary: The UN Security Council is meeting on the escalating humanitarian crisis in Gaza, where fresh Israeli evacuation orders have uprooted tens of thousands amid relentless bombardment claiming hundreds of civilian lives in recent weeks â€“ many of them children. â€œFood is running out. Those seeking it risk being shot. People are dying trying to feed their families,â€ UN relief chief Tom Fletcher has just told ambassadors. entry.title: Displacement, poverty and insecurity fueling violence against women in Gaza
entry.summary: In Gaza, illness, poverty, mass displacement and depleted services are leading to soaring stress levels and causing an increase in domestic violence, sexual exploitation and abuse, according to the UN sexual and reproductive health agency (UNFPA).

entry.title: Sudan: UNICEF condemns weekend attacks that killed 35 children

entry.title: Gaza: More misery as new evacuation orders impact tens of thousands
entry.summary: New evacuation orders in Gaza issued by the Israeli military have uprooted tens of thousands of Palestinians, amid ongoing bombardment, aid agencies have warned.

entry.title: This tree's destruction prompted outrageâ€”and now a guilty verdict
entry.summary:
The Sycamore Gap tree grew in the dip of an ancient Roman wall. A lone tree growing along an ancient Roman wall was a beloved fixture in the landscape. Why did the Sycamore Gap treeâ€™s illegal felling spark so much emotion?
In the early hours of September 28, 2023, an act of violence and vandalism shocked the U.K.
The next day, news of the attack dominated social media and mainstream news coverage, leading to outpourings of grief, fury at its senselessness, and pilgrimages to the remote stretch of countryside where the crime took place.
This wasnâ€™t a human tragedy.
In the dark of night, a solitary sycamore tree was cut down at an iconic stretch of an ancient ruin known as Hadrianâ€™s Wall in Northumberland in north east England. The wall is nearly 2,000 years old and Â hâ€¦

entry.title: What are â€˜blue zonesâ€™? 5 places where the healthiest people live
entry.summary:
Ogliastra in Sardinia, Italy, is one of five certified â€œblue zones,â€ where citizens tend to live long and happy lives. These blue zones have unlocked the secret to long life. Hereâ€™s what we can learn from them.
If you live in â€œblue zones,â€ thereâ€™s a good chance youâ€™ll live to be 100. Thatâ€™s what National Geographic Explorer Dan Buettner found.
Since 2004, Buettner has been studying places that not only have high concentrations of individuals over 100 years old, but also clusters of people who have grown old without health problems like heart disease, obesity, cancer, or diabetes.
His findings launched books including,Â The Blue Zones Secrets for Living Longer: Lessons From the Healthiest Places on Earth, worldwide interest in these hot spots, and even a Netflix series, â€œLiâ€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: About Pew Research Centerâ€™s Spring 2025 Global Attitudes Survey Results for the survey are based on a mix of telephone, face-to-face and online interviews conducted under the direction of Gallup, Langer Research Associates and Social Research Centre. The results are based on national samples, unless otherwise noted. Read more about ourÂ international survey methodology and country-specific [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Laura Silver,Â Associate Director, Global Attitudes ResearchLaura Clancy,Â Research AnalystJonathan Schulman,Â Research AssociateWilliam Miner,Â Research AnalystChristine Huang,Â Former Research Associate Dorene Asare-Marfo,Â Senior Panel ManagerPeter Bell,Â Associate Director, Design and ProductionJanakee Chavda,Â Associate Digital ProducerJonathan Evans,Â Senior ResearcherMoira Fagan,Â Research AssociateJanell Fetterolf,Â Senior ResearcherShannon Greenwood,Â Digital Production ManagerSneha Gubbala,Â Research AnalystSofia Hernandez [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix B: How people in middle-income countries see bilateral issues with the U.S. and China (detailed tables)
entry.summary: The post Appendix B: How people in middle-income countries see bilateral issues with the U.S. and China (detailed tables) appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix A: Global Attitudes Survey fieldwork timeline
entry.summary: There were many events, meetings and announcements that occurred shortly before and during our fieldwork period that may have impacted how people perceive China and its president. We highlight a few prominent events here that were relevant across multiple countries and directly relate to the questions included in our survey. The post Appendix A: Global Attitudes Survey fieldwork timeline appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. Where China is seen as an ally or threat
entry.summary: China is named as a top ally in sub-Saharan African and Latin American countries surveyed, but considered a top threat in the Asia-Pacific region. The post 4. Where China is seen as an ally or threat appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Views of China in middle-income countries
entry.summary: Across nine middle-income countries, people generally see investment from China as a good thing because it creates jobs. The post 3. Views of China in middle-income countries appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Chinaâ€™s economic power and economic relations
entry.summary: Across 25 countries, people increasingly view China as the world's top economy but generally prioritize economic ties with the U.S. The post 2. Chinaâ€™s economic power and economic relations appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1.Â Â Views of China and Xi Jinping
entry.summary: People across 25 nations are mostly unfavorable toward China and lack confidence in Xi, but views have improved in some places. The post 1.Â Â Views of China and Xi Jinping appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: International Views of China Turn Slightly More Positive
entry.summary: People in many of 25 surveyed nations increasingly see China as the worldâ€™s top economic power. The post International Views of China Turn Slightly More Positive appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Icelandic vibes, northern lightsâ€”and no crowds
entry.summary:
Visit the Yukon Territory to see the northern lights dance over snow-covered mountains. The Yukon Territory glowsâ€”but not with city lights. â€œEverywhere you look is like a paintingâ€ here, with auroras that last for hours, hot springs, and volcanic canyons.
The skies open up, and a tidal wave of green crosses the sky. The air is frigid and clear, and so too is the Klondike Highway. The auroras last for hours, the boreal forest glowing neon in the dark. Itâ€™s a scene many travelers dream of finding on their Iceland trip, but this oneâ€™s a painting of any winter night in Canadaâ€™s Yukon Territory.
While Iceland and the Yukon certainly share a long list of similaritiesâ€”fabulous outdoor adventure, midnight sun, spa culture, macabre drinking traditionsâ€”by the numbers, they couldnâ€™t tellâ€¦

entry.title: How to dig up 55 tons of dinosaur bones from the worldâ€™s fiercest desert
entry.summary:
As the Saharan sun rose on my waylaid team, one morning in September 2022, it seemed to burn with particular intensity. For nearly three weeks weâ€™d been holed up in a mud-walled compound in the oasis town of Agadez, in central Niger, stalled because of officialsâ€™ insistence on assembling for us a large armed escort. Now, as dawn broke, we were finally ready to embark: Nearly a hundred people packed into 15 vehicles, a motley caravan of SUVs, pickups, and one large dump truck, all strapped with sand ladders and spare tires, heading out on an extraordinary desert dinosaur huntâ€”without question, the most ambitious of my career.
Among our number were Tuareg guides and drivers, a film crew, 64 armed guards, and my paleo dream team of 20 students and freshly minted professors, recruited to â€¦

entry.title: Humans used to have straighter teethâ€”what changed?
entry.summary:
Studies of ancient skulls show wider jaws and fewer malocclusions, leading researchers to explore how diet and lifestyle shaped the human face. New research explores how diet, evolution, and facial anatomy may have shaped our modern smiles.
Braces, rubber bands, even jaw surgeryâ€”millions endure them in pursuit of a straighter smile. But were misaligned smiles always this common? Research suggests that might not be the case.
While malocclusionsâ€”crowded or misaligned teethâ€”have been found among our hunter-gatherer ancestors, they appear to be more prevalent in modern populations. So what changed? Experts say the answer isnâ€™t simple but point to one possible culprit: our diets. As we traded raw, tough foods for softer, more processed ones, the burden of chewing decreased, allowinâ€¦

entry.title: Tornado alley is moving eastâ€”and it's deadlier than ever
entry.summary:
Tornadoes are some of the most destructive natural disasters seen in the United States each year, and twisters areÂ 10 timesÂ more common inÂ Tornado Alley.
But forÂ tornado expertÂ Stephen Strader, the term Tornado Alley may be a bit outdated. â€œWe've had devastating tornadoes outside of what people consider Tornado Alley,â€Â the Villanova University associate professorÂ explains. And the disastrous phenomenon is only expected to get worse.Â Â Â Â Â
Drier conditions in the Great Plains, coupled with increased moisture in the Southeast isÂ shifting tornado activityÂ away from states like Texas, Oklahoma, and Kansas. Scientists attribute this shift to the east toÂ climate change.Â
â€œItâ€™s a very subtle shift,â€ Strader says. Cities like Dallas and Austin, Texas, are seeing four fewer tornado daâ€¦

entry.title: Hanoi or Ho Chi Minh Cityâ€”find out which one's right for you
entry.summary:
Hanoi is Vietnam's capital, a sophisticated thousand-year-old city whose heartbeat emanates from the Old Quarter. At opposite ends of the country, Vietnamâ€™s two major cities are a frenetic introduction to the nationâ€™s culture and history. If you only have time to explore one, hereâ€™s how to choose between them
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Hanoi may be Vietnamâ€™s capital, but Ho Chi Minh City isnâ€™t your ordinary â€˜second cityâ€™. Its appeal for travellers is on a par with Hanoiâ€™s, but the two cities have a very different atmosphere. Since Ho Chi Minh Cityâ€™s name was changed from â€˜Saigonâ€™ following the countryâ€™s reunification after the Vietnam War, itâ€™s evolved and grown exponentially. While Hanoi, in the north, is on the doorstep of popular attrâ€¦

entry.title: They used to poach this rare bird. Now, they save them.
entry.summary:
A Bengal florican sitting in long blades of grass. After decades of political unrest, former poachers and community members rallied to protect the Bengal florican.
During mating season, the male Bengal florican bird, in glossy black plumes with streaks of white beneath a mottled back, performs aerial leaps as his white wings flare against a neck â€œpouchâ€ of puffed black feathers to attract females. The enamoured female, draped in buff-brown and black, then chooses her mate. Â
Tourists now come to Manas National Park, a UNESCO World Heritage site in Assam, India, to see the Bengal floricans, the worldâ€™s rarest bustard, and other wildlife. But the birdsâ€™ resurgence has been a longâ€”and still challengingâ€”process.
Listed as critically endangered by the IUCN, fewer than 800 Benâ€¦

entry.summary: The ongoing 21-month-long war in Gaza has seen more than 58,000 killed and 100,000 wounded as Israeli attacks continue amid rising numbers of child deaths from malnutrition. In recent weeks, UN agencies have recorded nearly 900 deaths of desperate and hungry Gazans as they try to collect food â€“ with most linked to private aid hubs run by the so-called Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Scores killed in Sudanâ€™s Kordofan region as fighting intensifies
entry.summary: Intensifying clashes in Sudanâ€™s Kordofan region between rival militaries have killed hundreds and wounded many more in recent days, warned the UN humanitarian affairs office (OCHA) on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Global demand for meat and dairy set to rise, but climate and nutrition gaps remain
entry.summary: Global demand for meat, dairy and fish is projected to climb steadily over the next decade, driven by rising incomes and urbanisation in middle-income countries.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN urges de-escalation, protection of civilians as conflict roils Syria
entry.summary: Inter-ethnic violence in Syriaâ€™s predominantly Druze city of Sweida has been met with government intervention, Israeli airstrikes â€“ and on Tuesday, a reported ceasefire announcement by Syriaâ€™s defence minister.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Seeding gender empowerment: Women farmers in Peru contend with climate change
entry.summary: First, it was floods that inundated fields and washed away crops. Then, it was drought which led the levels of lakes to plummet and the crops to shrivel.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukraine: Civilians under fire in record numbers as attacks surge
entry.summary: Relentless missile and drone strikes by Russian forces have killed and injured hundreds of civilians in Ukraine this month, continuing a devastating pattern of attacks far from the frontlines.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: 875 people confirmed dead trying to source food in recent weeks
entry.summary: Nearly 900 desperate and hungry Gazans have been killed in recent weeks trying to fetchÂ food, with most deaths linked to private aid hubs run by the so-called Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF), the UN human rights office, OHCHR, said on Tuesday.

entry.title: Tips for Investigating New Oligarchs and Novel Corruption Ploys
entry.summary: The mega-rich oligarchs of the world have a surprising amount in common. Here are tips and resources for investigating their hidden assets and to finding out who is helping them.

entry.title: Why Aboriginal Australians are still fighting for recognition
entry.summary:
Aboriginal Australians are all related to a common group of ancestors who emerged on the mainland more than 50,000 years ago. Centuries after British colonization ravaged their population, these Indigenous Australians are still pushing for recognition of their sovereignty. They could be the oldest population of humans living outside of Africaâ€”yet Australia has still never made a treaty with Aboriginal Australians.
Australiaâ€™s first peopleâ€”known as Aboriginal Australiansâ€”have lived on the continent for over 65,000 years. Diverse and culturally distinctive, they are represented by more than 250 distinct language groups spread throughout Australia. About 3 percent of Australiaâ€™s population has Aboriginal heritage.
But the origins, and fate, of Australiaâ€™s native peoples are stillâ€¦

entry.title: 10 of the best hotels in Abu Dhabi for every type of traveler
entry.summary:
A father with his son in a stroller walks through the fountains outside the Emirates Palace Mandarin Oriental Hotel. Itâ€™s just one of 10 hotels and resorts that visitors should consider checking into when visiting Abu Dhabi. Plan an unforgettable stay in the Emirati capital with our picks for the top seaside resorts, remote desert escapes and towering skyscrapers.
Abu Dhabi, the capital of the United Arab Emirates,Â is the country's largerst emirate comprised of more than 200 islands, a culture-centric vibe, and vast stretches of desert. Whether youâ€™re looking to embrace Arabian opulence or escape it all with toes in the beach or desert sand, our list of the best hotels in the emirate has you covered.
Best for:Â Travelers with no fear of heights
Towering over Abu Dhabiâ€™s â€¦

entry.title: The essential guide to visiting Abu Dhabi
entry.summary:
In addition to its religious significance, Abu Dhabiâ€™s Sheikh Zayed Grand Mosque, a popular cultural attraction, highlights the late Sheikh Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyanâ€™s legacy and humanitarian contributions. White sand beaches, incredible museums, and a diversity of global cuisines await in the UAEâ€™s action-packed capital. Hereâ€™s our guide to where to stay, what to eat, and what to know before you visit.
Less famous, flashy, and busy than its neighborÂ Dubai, Abu Dhabi offers far more than just sun, skyscrapers, and five-star hotels. With pristine beaches, vast mangrove forests, an increasing number of world-class museums and art galleries, and a year-round calendar of sporting events, it challenges every stereotype about theÂ UAE. It surprises you in all the best ways.Â
Câ€¦

entry.title: 7 unforgettable experiences in Abu Dhabi
entry.summary:
A woman wearing the traditional arab dress, Abaya, takes a photo in the Sheik Zayed Grand Mosque of Abu Dhabi. Itâ€™s just one of seven things to do when visiting the capital of the UAE. From majestic mountains to stunning architecture to world-class art, hereâ€™s our insiderâ€™s guide to the best things to do in the capital of the UAE.
Abu Dhabi is a captivating blend of heritage and ambition. As the captial of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the largest emirate, it boasts sprawling deserts, rugged mountains, serene mangroves, and endless coastlines. With more than 200 islands, itâ€™s home to futuristic museums, traditional souks, opulent mosques, and thriving wildlife reserves. From deep-rooted Bedouin culture to cutting-edge architecture, here are seven experiences that showcase Abu â€¦

entry.title: Great white photographed underwater for first time near Maine
entry.summary:
A juvenile great white shark, about 10 feet long, swims beneath the surface about 15 miles off the coast of Harpswell, Maine. National Geographic photographer Brian Skerry has logged more than 10,000 hours under waterâ€”but he's never before snapped a photo of a great white in Maine before.
The nonprofit National Geographic Society, committed to illuminating and protecting the wonder of our world, funded Explorer Brian Skerry's work through a collaboration with Builders Vision.Â Learn moreÂ about the Societyâ€™s support of Explorers.
As soon as National Geographic photographer and explorer Brian Skerry locked eyes with the enormous animal, he knew immediately what was staring back at him. â€œThereâ€™s no mistaking that face,â€ he says.
A nearly 10-foot long great white shark was jâ€¦

entry.title: Yemen: Security Council extends UN mission in crucial port city amid escalating Red Sea strife
entry.summary: The Security Council on Monday renewed the mandate of the UN mission in Yemenâ€™s key port city of Hudaydah, as regional tensions spike and international concern mounts over recent Houthi rebel attacks on shipping in the Red Sea.

entry.title: Sudan: Humanitarian needs deepen amid rising hostilities and heavy rains
entry.summary: Escalating violence, displacement and heavy rains are deepening the needs of civilians caught in the war in Sudan, the UN humanitarian affairs office, OCHA, said on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Security Council renews UNâ€™s Haiti mission amid spiralling crises
entry.summary: Amid runaway gang violence and crumbling state authority, the Security Council on Monday unanimously extended the mandate of the UNâ€™s political mission in Haiti until the end of the year, amid escalating gang violence, political paralysis and a deepening humanitarian crisis threatening the countryâ€™s collapse.

entry.title: World News in Brief: Inter-ethnic violence in Syria, Indigenous Peoplesâ€™ rights, global information security
entry.summary: Clashes on Sunday between Sunni Bedouin tribal fighters and Druze militia have reportedly left at least 30 dead in Syriaâ€™s predominantly-Druze city of Sweida.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜A compass towards progressâ€™ â€“ but key development goals remain way off track
entry.summary: Global life expectancy increased by an astonishing five years between 2000 and 2019. And then since the COVID-19 pandemic, it slid backwards by almost two. More than 110 million children have entered school since 2015 â€“ but by 2023, 272 million children still had no access to the classroom.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: UNICEF mourns seven children killed queuing for water
entry.summary: The head of UN child rights agency UNICEF has called for Israel to review its rules of engagement in Gaza after seven children were killed while waiting for water at a distribution point.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: WHO urges rollout of first long-acting HIV prevention jab
entry.summary: A breakthrough HIV drug that only needs to be injected twice a year to offer near-total protection from the virus and developing AIDS should be made available â€œimmediatelyâ€ at pharmacies, clinics and via online consultations, theÂ UN health agency said on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: This Swiss town is an under-the-radar outdoor mecca
entry.summary:
Mountain biking, kite surfing, and hiking are all popular activities to do in Silvaplana, Switzerland. More remote than other popular Alpine destinations, Silvaplana was a favorite of Friedrich Nietzscheâ€”and is one of the few places in the world where you can kite surf and ski in the same day.
As the Maloja wind sweeps through the Engadin Valley like clockwork around noon, dozens of colorful kites soar over Silvaplana Lakeâ€”one of the few places in the world where you can kite surf against the backdrop of snow-powdered peaks.
Set in Eastern Switzerlandâ€™s canton of GraubÃ¼nden, Silvaplana once inspired Friedrich Nietzsche. The German philosopher was a frequent summer guest to the area, where he took many walks along Lake Silvaplana. According to the local lore, it was here where â€¦

entry.title: The Ground Zero shipwreck mystery might finally be solved
entry.summary: Museum of the City of New York curator William M. Williamson and historian James A. Kelly examine timbers, possibly from the Tyger, on view in a 1954 exhibition Shipyards of New York. The Museum of the City of New York is launching a new investigation into the remains of a vessel found beneath lower Manhattan during subway construction in 1916. A shipwreck mystery buried under Ground Zero could soon be solved, with scientists set to investigate whether a doomed 17th-century vesselâ€”captained by a Dutch explorer who settled Manhattanâ€”lies deep beneath the former Twin Towers. Visitors flock to the World Trade Center site to see its 9/11 memorial and museum, and honor victims of the 2001 terrorist attack. But few would know Ground Zero was once nothing but ocean, before lanâ€¦

entry.title: Australiaâ€™s famous pink lakes are disappearing
entry.summary:
Pink Lake, Hutt Lagoon, Western Australia, 2020. Tiny extremophiles give the salty lakes their rosy hue, but over-mining and climate change are threatening their existence.
Beside the ochre-colored gorges and turquoise coastlines of Western Australia lies a surprising hue: fuchsia pink. The stateâ€™s pink salt lakes have been a startling part of the landscape for thousands of years. Theyâ€™ve appeared in Dreamtime stories and family vacation photos (though in the age before digital photographs, says Tilo Massenbauer, an applied environmental scientist who has studied the pink lakes, if visitors took their film to be developed outside of Western Australia, the technician would say the machine was broken, the color settings off, otherwise how could a lake be that pink?).
More recentâ€¦

entry.title: Is your dog your 'furbaby'? It's not an obsessionâ€”it's science
entry.summary:
There's a good reason why so many people feel as attached to their pets as they do to their human childrenâ€”over the course of evolution, dogs have hijacked the human bonding pathway that ensures we protect our young. We all have at least one friend that treats their dog like an actual human child. Scientists think you shouldn't be a hater: Thereâ€™s 20,000 to 40,000 years of evolution causing them to behave that way.
Pause for a moment and gaze into the eyes of your dog. Do you feel overwhelmed by how cute they are? Or, perhaps, an irresistible urge to squeeze them?Â
Now think about your habits. Do you send them to daycare, dress them up in clothes, and bring them on vacations? Do you speak to them like a baby?
If so, youâ€™re not aloneâ€”after all, research shows our brains esâ€¦

entry.title: This dish is the one thing to try on Corfuâ€”here's why
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As a child, Sunday mornings were spent in the kitchen of my yiayia. My Greek grandmother â€” or yiayia â€” cooked in the whitewashed shack built by my grandfather to keep the scent of frying fish and spices away from the main house. Cloves and cinnamon spiked the air as a rich tomato sauce and beef short ribs simmered away, cooking for hours before the pasta it would be served with â€” thick bucatini or penne to soak up the richly spiced sauce â€” went into a separate pot.
Pastitsada or â€˜la pastizzadaâ€™ as the islandâ€™s Venetian colonisers called it, is a dish thatâ€™s been representative of Corfu for hundreds of years. Slow-cooked meat â€” beef, rabbit, rooster or, on occasion, octopus â€” is stewed in a deep-red tomato sauce forâ€¦

entry.title: Want to try a long-distance hike in the UK? Make it one of these
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Few nationalities have an appetite for long-distance walks quite like the British. Even on an island prone to seaborne storms â€” where spring can segue directly into autumn and where upland visibility can extend no further than an outstretched hand â€” countless anorak-clad souls tramp a substantial network of long-distance paths: from the South West Coast Path riding atop the granite cliffs at Landâ€™s End in Cornwall, to the Cape Wrath Trail ending at a lonely lighthouse in the Scottish Highlands.
Long-distance rambling in Britain is part ofÂ aÂ correspondingly long tradition. In one sense, the activity began here in 1965 with the unveiling of the Pennine Way â€”Â a 268-mile route along the spine of Northern England, conneâ€¦

entry.title: How pizza omakase became a trend and where to try it
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
If youâ€™ve ever looked at the menu in a pizzeria and been blinded by indecision, then pizza omakase might be for you â€“ the food trend that gives you licence to sample a slice of everything. Â
Meaning â€˜I leave it up to youâ€™ in Japanese, omakase traditionally refers to the experience of sitting around a small sushi counter while the chef expertly crafts perfect sushi in front of you. Eschewing such workaday formalities as a menu, they hand you delicate slices of fish and rice with reverence, adapting whatâ€™s served to your tastes and desires.
As a catch-all term for leaving your dinner decisions in the hands of the chef, omakase is an intimate, often high-end tasting menu experience thatâ€™s taken off around the worâ€¦

entry.title: UN forum to spotlight health, gender equality, oceans, in critical bid to meet development goals
entry.summary: As the deadline for the 2030 Agenda looms, ministers, experts, and civil society leaders from around the world will convene in New York next week for a high-level UN forum to fast-track action on the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN-backed labour standards at risk as tariff uncertainty grows
entry.summary: Garment factories around the world which have signed up to implement UN-backed labour standards may simply stop investing in improving working conditions, due to widespread uncertainty over tariff levels, according to the International Labour Organization (ILO).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: The rebellious French island shaped by time and tradition: Corsica
entry.summary:
Corte, a picture-book huddle of medieval houses set on a hilltop citadel, rises imposingly above the maquis. A spirit of defiance and a mysterious culture endure on the French island of Corsica, intertwined with the timeless beauty of its fragrant shrubbery, rugged mountains and medieval villages.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Thereâ€™s something contrarian about Corsica, the fourth-largest island in the Mediterranean Sea. Seen from above, it resembles a hand with its index finger raised in defiance â€” the digit in question being the Cap Corse, a rugged peninsula of dark green mountains, bobbing fishing boats and beaches like Plage de Barcaggio, untouched by human development and famed for its herd of sunbathing cows.
Corsicaâ€™s story is oâ€¦

entry.title: Smurf your voice: Global campaign urges everyone to speak up for a better future
entry.summary: The Smurfs are back â€“ and this time they are smurfing up a global storm. Teaming up with the UN Childrenâ€™s Fund (UNICEF) and Paramount Pictures, the iconic blue characters are leading a campaign that encourages children and grownups everywhere to â€œSpeak Upâ€ for a better world.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: No fuel, no aid, no escape: UN agencies warn of looming collapse in Gaza
entry.summary: The fuel crisis in Gaza has reached a breaking point, threatening to bring all humanitarian operations to a halt and endangering the lives of everyone reliant on aid inside the enclave, UN agencies warned in a powerful joint statement on Saturday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World Horse Day: Honoring humanityâ€™s oldest and most loyal companion
entry.summary: Spacious paddocks, green pastures, and a devoted all-female staff: on Long Island, a strip of land surrounded by the Atlantic Ocean near New York City, horses once destined for slaughter are given a second chance â€“ to live, and to help people heal. The farm, founded in 2010 by Marisa Striano, is named after her beloved horse, Spiritâ€™s Promise. It offers healing â€“ for both horses and humans in need.

entry.title: What is cloud seeding? Here's what the tech canâ€”and can'tâ€”do
entry.summary:
Damaged trees and debris scattered along the banks of the Guadalupe River in the Texas Hill Country on July 5, 2025. In the days following, rumors circulated that a weather modification technology known as cloud seeding was responsible for the deluge. Scientists say this technology could not have produced such a storm. For years, scientists have experimented with engineering techniques that can safely modify rainfall. But experts say the technology isn't capable of causing extreme, sudden flooding.
In the wake of disastrous floods in Texas, concerns about cloud seeding technology have run rampant.
The technology sounds fantasticalâ€”like the doings of a comic book villainâ€”but scientists say the real impact of the technology is less than nefarious.Â
Today, cloud seeding is mâ€¦

entry.title: How vampires became allergic to the sun
entry.summary: In the 1922 film, Nosferatu, the main character gets struck by sunlight and bursts into flames a few seconds later. This moment caused a key shift in vampire folklore, creating the concept that vampires are night creatures who are unable to exist in the sunlight. The trope of vampires burning in the sun is a 20th century inventionâ€”but daywalkers are making a comeback.  Thanks to centuries of folklore, novels, movies, and TV shows, the tropes of vampires are carved deep into the popular imagination: The creatures drink blood, sleep in coffins, recoil from garlic and crucifixes, and are susceptible to a wooden stake through the heart. Perhaps most of all, theyâ€™re creatures of the night who canâ€™t handle daylight. But thatâ€™s not always the case. Some vampire stories eâ€¦

entry.title: Why you need to see this medieval-style German tournament
entry.summary:
Ulm's fisherfolk jousting imaginatively presents the city's history through characters like the police (left) and the â€˜Krettaweberâ€™ (right), the infamously bad-mouthed vegetable seller. In July, the southern German city of Ulm transforms its river into a dramatic stage where costumed jousters in boats vie for glory and try to avoid a watery plunge.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As two flat-bottomed river boats steer towards each other from either bank, powered along by a crew of three oarsmen, thousands of knuckles tense. The route is short, the boats cutting swiftly across the Danube to the sound of pounding drums. All eyes are on the two costumed men, each standing at the stern of his boat with a lance positioned on his hip.
The aim:â€¦

entry.title: Take a road trip through New Yorkâ€™s Finger Lakes
entry.summary:
If you have the time, hike the Watkins Glen Gorge Trail to Rainbow Falls. Find otherworldly white deer, roaring waterfalls, quirky towns, fascinating Indigenous history, and four vibrant seasons in this endlessly captivating region.
While the bright lights and skyscrapers of the eponymous metropolis often come to mind when picturing New York, once you step beyond the five boroughs, the state is often overlooked for its diversity of magical scenery rivaling much bigger states out west. The Empire State, the only one in the country with both Atlantic and Great Lake coastline, also comes equipped with three majestic mountain ranges, countless enchanting verdant forests, and perhaps its most underrated treasure among its endless captivating bodies of waterâ€”the Finger Lakes.Â Â
Etchâ€¦

entry.title: Manhattanhenge is here. How to see New York City's best sunset.
entry.summary:
Prepare for social mediaâ€™s favorite sunset.Â
On Friday and Saturday evening, July 11 and 12, the sun will line up perfectly with Manhattanâ€™s grid, turning the cityâ€™s streets into glowing corridors of light. This rare and radiant moment, called Manhattanhenge, provides picture perfect views straight to New Jersey. New Yorkers can catch it both nights around 8:20 p.m., weather permitting.
Manhattanhenge was named by astrophysicist and National Geographic Explorer Neil deGrasse Tyson, who was inspired by Stonehenge in Wiltshire, England. As head of the American Museum of Natural Historyâ€™s Hayden Planetarium, he began calculating the dates in the late 1990s. He coined the term in 2002, according to The New York Times, though there are references to â€œsolar grid dayâ€ going back to the â€¦

entry.title: Superpowers are realâ€”these people are living proof
entry.summary:
It may not be a superpower from a sci-fi show, but the Bajau people of the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia have evolved a genetic ability to use oxygen more efficiently. This makes them excellent free divers, like fisherman Dafrin Ambotang, pictured here, in the Togian Islands, Indonesia, who can dive for up to four minutes on one breath. Scientists say that through genetics or training, even mere mortals can develop superhuman powers.
Superpowers are real. Okay, maybe humans canâ€™t leap tall buildings in a single bound like Superman or shoot energy beams from their eyes like Cyclops. But our bodies and brains hold the potential for many seemingly superhuman feats, scientists say.
Sometimes real-life superpowers arise through genetic mutations, not unlike the origin storieâ€¦

entry.title: French presidents come here to unwind. You can too.
entry.summary:
Since 2014, the Fort de BrÃ©ganÃ§on has been open to the public for three-hour guided tours. Few international visitors make it to this corner of the Mediterranean, where Franceâ€™s head of state has vacationed since the 1960s. From a tour of the impressive fort itself, to the surrounding villages and vineyards, hereâ€™s why itâ€™s worth a trip.
Picture the French Riviera and F. Scott Fitzgerald-level hedonism may spring to mind: Bronzed revelers quaffing Champagne on the beach, stars strutting the red carpet at the Cannes Film Festival, super yachts cruising the Mediterranean offshore. But few international visitors frequent the idyllic stretch of coast to the west of Saint-Tropez.
Backed by hillside nature reserves blanketed in cork oak forest, this dreamy shoreline also happens to â€¦

entry.title: Why Europeâ€™s wine lovers are heading to the Peloponnese
What this shipwreck teaches about the horrors of slavery
entry.summary:
"A View Of The Cape of Good Hope, Taken on the Spot, From on Board the 'Resolution,' Capt. Cooke" by English landscape painter William Hodges, 1772. For more than 200 years, the SÃ£o JosÃ© Paquete dâ€™Africa lay hidden off Cape Townâ€™s shore. Its excavation in 2014 uncovered a tragic story of enslavement and commerce from the time of the trans-Atlantic slave trade.
For three weeks, since the Portuguese SÃ£o JosÃ© Paquete dâ€™Africa lifted anchor in Mozambique, the 512 enslaved Mozambicans crammed into its hold had been living a nightmare of seasickness, dehydration, disease, and degradation. Ahead lay a harrowing four-month crossing to MaranhÃ£o, Brazil, followed by a lifetime of forced labor in the cane fields.
On the voyage perhaps 20 percent would die, the average mortality rateâ€¦

entry.title: Explore the elaborate tomb of Nefertari
entry.summary: Queen Nefertari, â€œbeloved of Mut,â€ lived during the 19th dynasty (13th century B.C.) and was a Great Royal Wife of Pharaoh Ramses II. She was most likely his favorite and the most powerful of them. Nefertari was showered with numerous honorific titles, including Great Royal Wife, Wife of God, Mother of Pharaoh, Hereditary Noblewoman, and Mistress of Upper and Lower Egypt. However, one title, She for Whom the Sun Shines, points to Ramsesâ€™ special love for Nefertari. He built a magnificent tomb for her in the necropolis at the Valley of the Queens, or Ta Set Neferu (â€œthe place of the beautiesâ€) as the ancient Egyptians called it. The site is south of the Valley of the Kings, and the layout is characteristic of tombs from the time of the New Kingdom. It was excavated out of the rocky mountainâ€¦

entry.title: Fireflies are flourishing in places you wouldn't expect
entry.summary:
For many people across the United States, summer doesnâ€™t truly begin until the soft glow of electric yellow and green fireflies can be seen drifting through the night.
But you donâ€™t have to travel to the deep woods or open prairie to experience these otherworldly insects. In fact, several firefly species can be found quietly blinking in the heart of some of the United Statesâ€™ largest cities.
â€œItâ€™s the last place you would expect to see fireflies,â€ says Sriram Murali, an International Union for Conservation of Nature Species Survival Commission firefly specialist and National Geographic Explorer.
This summer, Murali traveled to New York City and Washington, D.C. to photograph urban fireflies as a way to show how resilient some species are in the face of one of their greatest â€¦

entry.title: Scientists find a royal Maya tomb filled with treasures
entry.summary:
Caana, which means "sky palace" in Mayan, is the largest structure at Caracol, Belize, rises over 140 feet above the jungle. Researchers recently found a tomb under the canopy in an acropolis to the immediate right of Caana. Found in the ancient city of Caracol, the tomb contained a rare jade mask, ceramics, and jewelry often linked to the Maya ruling class.
Deep in the dense jungles of Belize, archaeologists excavating the ancient Maya city of Caracol have unearthed what they believe to be the 1,700-year-old tomb of a ruler. If confirmed, the discovery would mark the siteâ€™s earliest known royal burial, and possibly the resting place of its founding king, Te Kâ€™ab Chaak.Â
â€œThis is an extremely important discovery,â€ says Francisco Estrada-Belli, an archaeologist at Tulane Uâ€¦

entry.title: Here's what a solar tornado looks like
entry.summary:
From a dark sky site in Portugal's Alqueva Dark Sky Reserve, Portuguese astrophotographer Miguel Claro captured stellar views of the sunâ€™s chromosphereâ€”the orange-red layer of the sun's atmosphereâ€”over the last few years.
The sun produces energy in its core through a process called nuclear fusion. That energy travels outward to the sunâ€™s atmosphere, producing an extremely complex and dynamic environment with a variety of special phenomena, including solar tornadoes and solar prominences.
â€œPhotographing the sun is as demanding as it is incredible,â€ Claro says. When he looks at the sun through his equipment, he sees â€œthat the sun is always featuring something newâ€”something that wasnâ€™t there the day before.â€
Below is a slew of fascinating features captured from our host star.
This time-lapse, taken April 24, 2025, showcases a twister on the sun. A solar tornado is created when magnetic fields swirl a tornado-like filament of boiling plasma in the sunâ€™s atmosphere. According to NASAâ€™s space-based Solar Dynamics Observatory, they can rotate at speeds up to 186,000 miles per hour. (For comparison, tornadoes on Earth only reach speeds of 300 miles per hour.) Scientists estimate there are as many as 11,000 solar tornadoes above the sunâ€™s surface at any given moment. The solar chromosphere is seen on May 10, 2024, showing the most severe geomagnetic storm of the past 20 years, which created aurora borealis phenomena across the Northern hemisphere. A large solar prominence captured on April 24, 2025. On May 10, 2024, one of the most severe solar storms in over two decades hit Earth. Solar storms happen when sudden, strong bursts of charged particles from the sun hit Earth's atmosphere. They can trigger a beautiful light show in the form of auroras and can also wreak havoc on earthly technologies like power grids and our fleet of space-based satellites.

entry.title: Booze was banned to protect womenâ€”but it actually empowered them
entry.summary:
For women drink openly during Prohibition. The nationwide alcohol ban, enacted in 1920 to curb social ills including domestic violence, restricted drinking across the boardâ€”but also opened new social and economic spaces for women, who had previously been excluded from saloons and the liquor trade. Prohibition aimed to curb male violence. Instead, it gave rise to female bootleggers, policy advocates, and a cultural shift toward equality.
In June 1920, The New York Times reported that William Hartman shot and killed his wife, just after returning from a night of drinking whiskey.
Itâ€™s impossible to know what led to his actions. But stories like his appeared with disturbing regularity in newspapers during the early 20th century, illustrating the very dangers that Temperance advocâ€¦

entry.title: 6 of the most unusual places to stay at U.S. national parks
entry.summary: Travelers can marvel at the natural wonder of Kilauea from the comfort of the Volcano House, located near the volcano's summit at Hawaiâ€™i Volcanoes National Park. A room with a view of one of the worldâ€™s most active volcanoes? A lodge that echoes The Shining? These six hotels and resorts are once-in-a-lifetime experiences. Lava eruptions, ghost towns, stargazing beds, and horror films are features of the most unusual accommodations in or near U.S. national parks. Visitors to these 63 majestic parks can choose from a variety of traditional options, including convenient motels, cozy lodges, luxurious cabins, and modern hotels. Or they can add a curious twist to their wilderness holiday by staying in one of these six distinctive properties.Â  Great Smoky Mountains Naâ€¦

entry.title: Our solar system has a new mysterious visitorâ€”what is it?
entry.summary:
The interstellar comet, originally called A11pl3Z and now known as 3I/Atlas, was first reported by the Asteroid Terrestrial-impact Last Alert System (Atlas) survey telescope at El Sauce Observatory in RÃ­o Hurtado, Chile. Just the third-ever confirmed interstellar object has been detected in our solar system. Here's what we know. (Spoiler: It's not aliens.)
On July 1, scientists operating a planetary defense facility saw something glimmering in the shadow of Jupiter, about 420 million miles from Earth. It certainly wasnâ€™t a near-Earth asteroid, nor was it a regular comet. Within a matter of hours, it became clear that this voyager wasnâ€™t even from our solar system: Its orbit was too steep, its speed was too great. Astronomers quickly concluded that this was an interstellar objectâ€”a â€¦

entry.title: Methodology
